img.alt: A cross-section of four horizontal rock layers. The top layer is labeled A, the one below it is B, the next is C, and the bottom layer is D.

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: If these rock layers have been undisturbed, which layer is the youngest?
qti-choice-interaction.qti-simple-choice: A Correct! In undisturbed rock layers, the youngest layer is always on top. This is the principle of superposition.
B Layer B is older than layer A. Remember that in undisturbed rock layers, younger layers form on top of older layers.
C Layer C is older than both layers A and B above it. Rock layers are deposited from bottom to top, making the topmost layer the youngest.
D Layer D is the oldest layer, not the youngest. It's at the bottom because it was deposited first, before all the other layers.

qti-content-body.p: Correct! Layer A is the youngest. According to the principle of superposition, in undisturbed sedimentary rock layers, the oldest layers are at the bottom and the youngest are at the top. Each layer was deposited on top of the layer below it.

Not quite. Think about how rock layers form. New sediment is deposited on top of existing layers. In undisturbed rock formations, this means the youngest layer will always be at the top (layer A) and the oldest at the bottom (layer D).
